unnormalised: Someone asked me how much I typically donate to charity in a year. It’s a tricky question, honestly. It really depends on the year and what’s happening. I try to earmark around 2% of my annual income but sometimes life happens. Last year, I ended up donating approx. Rs. 25,000 to various causes. That included Rs. 5000 to a local NGO that helps underprivileged children with their education, and another Rs. 10000 to a disaster relief fund after the Kerala floods.
normalised: Someone asked me how much I typically donate to charity in a year. It’s a tricky question, honestly. It really depends on the year and what’s happening. I try to earmark around two percent of my annual income but sometimes life happens. Last year, I ended up donating approximately rupee twenty five thousand to various causes. That included rupee five thousand to a local N-G-O that helps underprivileged children with their education, and another rupee ten thousand to a disaster relief fund after the Kerala floods.

unnormalised: My family also has a tradition of donating to our local temple during Diwali. We usually contribute around Rs. 2100 each year. It's not a huge amount, but it’s something we've been doing for generations. I also sometimes donate smaller amounts, like Rs. 50 or Rs. 100, to beggars or street performers, but I don’t really keep track of that. Those are more spontaneous acts of kindness, I suppose.

unnormalised: This year, I'm hoping to donate more. I’m thinking of setting up a recurring donation of Rs. 250/month to an animal shelter. I saw they’re struggling and need help feeding the animals. My friend, Aisha, also told me about a campaign raising money for cancer patients, where they aim to collect Rs. 5 Lakh. I might contribute a larger sum to that.

unnormalised: Ultimately, I don’t think about the exact amount that much. I believe in giving what I can, when I can. Whether it's Rs. 5 or Rs. 5000, every bit counts. The real reward is knowing you've made a small difference in someone else's life.
